facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 205 of 1961 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 205 of 1961. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated June 16, 1959, of the Bombay High Court  Circuit Bench  at Nagpur in F. A. No. 32 of 1955.

facts.text: Appeal was from the judgment and decree dated June 16, 1959, of the Bombay High Court Circuit Bench at Nagpur in F.A. No. 32 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated June 16, 1959, of the Bombay High Court  Circuit Bench  at Nagpur in F. A. No. 32 of 1955. Shankar Anand, M. S. Gupta and Ganpot Rai for the appellants.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court was delivered on March 30, 1962 by VENKATARAMA AIYAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. March 30. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AIYAR, J.-The sole point for determination in this appeal, which is directed against the Judgment of the High Court of Bombay is whether the appellant is number liable to pay tax under the provisions of the Central Provinces Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947  Act 21 of 1947 , on the ground alleged that it had number been validly registered as a dealer under s.8 of the Act.

facts.text: Central Provinces Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 (Act 21 of 1947) received assent of Governor-General on May 23, 1947 and came into force on June 1, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The facts bearing on this companytention are that the Central Provinces Berar Sales Tax Act, hereinafter referred to as the Act, received the assent of the Governor-General on May 23, 1947 and came into force on June 1, 1947. On May 27, 1947 a numberification No. 601 was issued by the Provincial Government publishing draft rules which it proposed to make, in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 28 of the Act and on August 15, 1947, the rules as finally adopted were published.

facts.text: Notification No. 601 issued on May 27, 1947 by Provincial Government publishing draft rules under s.28 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On May 27, 1947 a numberification No. 601 was issued by the Provincial Government publishing draft rules which it proposed to make, in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 28 of the Act and on August 15, 1947, the rules as finally adopted were published.

facts.text: Rules finally adopted published on August 15, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: ...and on August 15, 1947, the rules as finally adopted were published. In the meantime two other numberifications Nos. 597 and 599 had been issued on May 27, 1947, No. 597 under s.8 of the Act fixing August 15, 1947 as the date by or on which all dealers liable to pay tax under the said Act shall get themselves registered...

facts.text: Notification No. 597 issued on May 27, 1947 under s.8 fixing August 15, 1947 as date for dealers to register.

anchor.surface_text: In the meantime two other numberifications Nos. 597 and 599 had been issued on May 27, 1947, No. 597 under s.8 of the Act fixing August 15, 1947 as the date by or on which all dealers liable to pay tax under the said Act shall get themselves registered and No. 599 under s.3 of the Act appointing the District Excise Officers as the Sales Tax officers for receiving applications for registration and for issuing certificates under section 8 of the Act.

facts.text: Notification No. 599 issued on May 27, 1947 under s.3 appointing District Excise Officers as Sales Tax Officers for registration under s.8.

anchor.surface_text: ...and No. 599 under s.3 of the Act appointing the District Excise Officers as the Sales Tax officers for receiving applications for registration and for issuing certificates under section 8 of the Act. The appellant is a Company carrying on business in the manufacture and sale of potteries chinaware in Nagpur.

facts.text: Appellant is a company carrying on business in manufacture and sale of potteries chinaware in Nagpur.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a Company carrying on business in the manufacture and sale of potteries chinaware in Nagpur. On July 2, 1947 it- presented, pursuant to the numberifications aforesaid, an application to the Sales-Tax Officer for registering itself as a dealer under the Act.

facts.text: Appellant presented application for registration to Sales Tax Officer on July 2, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On July 2, 1947 it- presented, pursuant to the numberifications aforesaid, an application to the Sales-Tax Officer for registering itself as a dealer under the Act. On this application a certificate was issued on July 21, 1947 and actually delivered to the appellant on September 13, 1947.

facts.text: Registration certificate issued to appellant on July 21, 1947 and delivered on September 13, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On this application a certificate was issued on July 21, 1947 and actually delivered to the appellant on September 13, 1947. Thereafter the appellant had been duly submitting returns as provided in the Act and assessment were made thereon and taxes paid from the period companymencing from June 1, 1947 to June 30, 1951.

facts.text: Appellant submitted returns and paid taxes from June 1, 1947 to June 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the appellant had been duly submitting returns as provided in the Act and assessment were made thereon and taxes paid from the period companymencing from June 1, 1947 to June 30, 1951. Some time thereafter the idea dawned on the appellant that the proceedings taken by the respondents under the Act were unauthorised, that the assessments were illegal...

facts.text: Appellant instituted suit on December 18, 1951 claiming refund of Rs. 6,650-11-9 sales tax paid from June 1, 1947 to June 30, 1951 and Rs. 2,000 damages.

anchor.surface_text: And so, on December 18, 1951, it instituted the suit out of which the present appeal arises claiming a refund of Rs. 6,650-11-9 being the amount paid for, sales tax during the period June 1, 1947 to June 30, 1951 and a sum of Rs. 2,000/- as damages, in all Rs. 8,650-11-9.

facts.text: Petitioner's contention: Sales Tax Officer who issued certificate on July 21, 1947 not authorised under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Though a number of grounds were put forward in support of the claim, it is necessary number to deal with only one of them, and that is that the Sales Tax Officer who issued the registration certificate to the appellant on July 21, 1947 was number authorised to do so under that Act...

facts.text: Notification No. 595 dated May 27, 1947 appointed Excise Commissioner as Commissioner of Sales Tax.

anchor.surface_text: By numberification No. 595 dated May 27, 1947 the Government appointed in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 3 1  the Excise Commissioner, Central Provinces Berar to be the Commissioner of Sales Tax, Central Provinces Berar.

facts.text: Civil Judge of Nagpur dismissed the suit holding irregularity cured and liability not affected by invalid registration.

anchor.surface_text: The Civil Judge of Nagpur who tried the suit held that as the certificate of registration was delivered to the appellant on September 13, 1947 i.e. after the rules had been finally published on August 15, 1947, the irregularity, if any, in the issue of registration certificate on July 21, 1947 bad been cured.

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeal to High Court of Nagpur, transferred to Bombay High Court Circuit Bench at Nagpur under States Reorganisation Act.

anchor.surface_text: Against this decision appellant preferred an appeal to the High Court of Nagpur and that was heard by a Bench of the Bombay High Court to which it stood transferred under the States Reorganisation Act.

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed appeal on June 16, 1959 holding liability to tax irrespective of registration validity, granted certificate under s.109 CPC and Art.132 Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held that the question whether the registration of the appellant as dealer under s. 8 of the Act was valid or number did number call for a decision as even if it was invalid that did number affect its liability to be assessed to sales tax... granted a certificate under s. 109 C.P.C. and Art. 132 2  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Supreme Court held appellant liable to pay tax under s.4 irrespective of registration under s.8 validity.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court is clearly companyrect in its view that the appellant was liable to pay the tax under the Act irrespective of whether the registration under s. 8 was valid or number. That liability arose under s. 4 which is the charging ,section.

facts.text: Appellant submitted returns voluntarily under s.10(1) on which assessments were made.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had itself, acting under s. 10 1  been submitting voluntarily returns on which the assessments had been made and it is number idle for it to companytend that the proceedings taken on its own returns are without jurisdiction.
provisions of the Central Provinces Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947  Act 21 of 1947 , on the ground alleged that it had number been validly registered

anchor.surface_text: an appeal to the High Court of Nagpur and that was heard by a Bench of the Bombay High Court to which it stood transferred under the States Reorganisation Act.

issues.text: whether the appellant is not liable to pay tax under the provisions of the Central Provinces Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947 (Act 21 of 1947), on the ground alleged that it had not been validly registered as a dealer under s.8 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The sole point for determination in this appeal, which is directed against the Judgment of the High Court of Bombay is whether the appellant is number liable to pay tax under the provisions of the Central Provinces Berar Sales Tax Act, 1947  Act 21 of 1947 , on the ground alleged that it had number been validly registered as a dealer under s.8 of the Act.

issues.text: whether the Sales Tax Officer who issued the registration certificate to the appellant on July 21, 1947 was not authorised to do so under that Act

anchor.surface_text: that the Sales Tax Officer who issued the registration certificate to the appellant on July 21, 1947 was number authorised to do so under that Act and in companysequence all the assessments and recoveries of tax were illegal and void. The basis for this companytention is that s. 3 1  of the Act companyfers authority on the State Government to appoint any person to be a Commissioner of Sales Tax, and such other persons under any prescribed designations to assist him as it thinks fit.

issues.text: whether the registration of the appellant as dealer under s. 8 of the Act was valid or not

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held that the question whether the registration of the appellant as dealer under s. 8 of the Act was valid or number did number call for a decision as even if it was invalid that did number affect its liability to be assessed to sales tax

issues.text: whether even if registration under s. 8 invalid, that affects liability to pay tax under s.4

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court is clearly companyrect in its view that the appellant was liable to pay the tax under the Act irrespective of whether the registration under s. 8 was valid or number. That liability arose under s. 4 which is the charging ,section.

issues.text: whether the jurisdiction of the Sales Tax Officer to take proceedings for assessment with respect to non-registered dealers depends on the issue of a notice under s.10 and rule 22, and if absent renders assessment incompetent

anchor.surface_text: It was argued for the appellant that it would make a difference in the procedure prescribed for making assessment whether a dealer was registered or number. It was said that under s. 10 1  while every registered dealer is under an obligation to make returns for the purposes of assessment, a dealer who is number registered becomes liable to send the return only if he is required to do so by the Commissioner by numberice served in the prescribed manner and Rule 22

issues.text: whether there is a distinction between want of jurisdiction (nullity, open to collateral attack) and irregular assumption of jurisdiction (valid unless challenged directly)

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection it should be remembered that there is a fundamental distinction between want of jurisdiction and irregular assumption of jurisdiction, and that whereas an order passed by an authority with respect to a mattar over which it has numberjurisdiction is a nullity and is open to companylateral attack, an order passed by an authority which has jurisdiction over the matter, but has assumed it otherwise than in the mode prescribed by law, is number a nullity.

issues.text: whether even if proceedings for assessment taken without notice under s.10(1), it is mere irregularity not affecting validity, especially when dealer submitted returns voluntarily

anchor.surface_text: Therefore even if the proceedings for assessment were taken against a number-registered dealer without the isssue of a numberice under s. 10  1  that would be a mere irregularity in the assumption of jurisdiction and the order of assessment passed in those proceedings cannot be held to be Without jurisdiction and numbersuit will lie for impeaching them on the ground that s. 10  1  had number been followed. This must a fortiori be so when the appellant has itself submitted to jurisdiction and made a return.

issues.text: whether the suit is maintainable in view of s.21 barring jurisdiction of civil courts to question orders under the Act

anchor.surface_text: We should add that s. 21 of the Act bare the jurisdiction of Civil Courts to entertain suits calling in question any orders passed by the authorities under the Act, and in the view which we have taken it is unnecessary to go into the question whether in view of this section the present suit is maintainable.

arguments.claim: The Sales Tax Officer who issued the registration certificate to the appellant on July 21, 1947 was not authorised to do so under the Act because the appointment under Notification No. 599 was in contravention of s.3(1) as 'prescribed' means by rules under s.2(e) which were not in force until August 15, 1947

anchor.surface_text: Though a number of grounds were put forward in support of the claim, it is necessary only to deal with only one of them, and that is that the Sales Tax Officer who issued the registration certificate to the appellant on July 21, 1947 was not authorised to do so under that Act and in consequence all the assessments and recoveries of tax were illegal and void. The basis for this contention is that s. 3 (1) of the Act confers authority on the State Government to appoint any person to be a Commissioner of Sales Tax, and such other persons under any prescribed designations to assist him as it thinks fit.

arguments.claim: The irregularity, if any, in the issue of the registration certificate on July 21, 1947 had been cured because the certificate was delivered on September 13, 1947 after the rules were published on August 15, 1947

anchor.surface_text: The Civil Judge of Nagpur who tried the suit held that as the certificate of registration was delivered to the appellant on September 13, 1947 i.e. after the rules had been finally published on August 15, 1947, the irregularity, if any, in the issue of registration certificate on July 21, 1947 bad been cured.

arguments.claim: The liability of the appellant to pay sales tax was not affected by the invalidity of the registration under s.8

anchor.surface_text: He also further held that the liability of the appellant to pay sales tax was not affected by the invalidity of the registration under s. 8. In the result he dismissed the suit with costs.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to obtain a certificate. It was argued for the appellant that it would make a difference in the procedure prescribed for making assessment whether a d

arguments.court_reasoning: Liability arises under s.4 independently of s.8 registration

arguments.claim: The question whether the registration of the appellant as dealer under s.8 of the Act was valid or not does not call for a decision as even if invalid it does not affect liability to be assessed to sales tax

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges held that the question whether the registration of the appellant as dealer under s. 8 of the Act was valid or not did not call for a decision as even if it was invalid that did not affect its liability to be assessed to sales tax... granted a certificate under s. 109 C.P.C. and Art. 132 (2) of the Constitution.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: to obtain a certificate. It was argued for the appellant that it would make a difference in the procedure prescribed for making assessment whether a d

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed that High Court correct; liability under s.4 irrespective of s.8

arguments.claim: The appellant was liable to pay the tax under the Act irrespective of whether the registration under s.8 was valid or not; liability arose under s.4 the charging section

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court is clearly correct in its view that the appellant was liable to pay the tax under the Act irrespective of whether the registration under s. 8 was valid or not. That liability arose under s. 4 which is the charging ,section.

arguments.claim: Liability to tax under s.4 is not conditional on registration under s.8; s.8(1) prohibits business without registration but does not affect substantive liability

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 is as follows- (4)(1)(a). In Madhya Pradesh excluding the merged territories every dealer whose turnover during the year preceding the commencement of this Act exceeded the taxable quantum shall be liable to pay tax... This liability is not conditional on the registration of the dealer under s. 8. Section 8 (1) enacts that no dealer shall, while being liable to pay tax under this Act carry on business as a dealer unless he has been registered as such and possesses a registration certificate .

arguments.claim: A dealer failing to register loses benefit of s.11(1) assessment on returns but not absolved from liability under s.4; invalid registration same as no registration

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 (1) provides that If the Commissioner is satisfied that the returns furnished by a registered dealer in respect of any period are correct and complete, he shall assess the dealer on them. These provisions do not, to any extent effect the substantive liability to be assessed to tax which is imposed by s. 4.A dealer who fails to get himself registered would be hit by s. 8 (1) and may loss the benefit conferred by s. 11 (1) but the Act does not put him in a better position than a dealer who has got himself registered under s. 8 (1) and absolve him from his liability to pay tax under s. 4.

arguments.claim: Procedure for assessment differs for registered vs non-registered dealers; non-registered require notice under s.10(1) and Rule 22; no notice issued so if registration invalid assessments incompetent

anchor.surface_text: The position of the dealer who has obtained a certificate of registration which turns out to be invalid cannot on principle, be distinguish from that of one who has failed to obtain a certificate. It was argued for the appellant that it would make a difference in the procedure prescribed for making assessment whether a dealer was registered or not. It was said that under s. 10 (1) while every registered dealer is under an obligation to make returns... Rule 22 which has been framed... requiring him to furnish returns. It is contended that the jurisdiction of the Sales Tax Officer to take proceedings for assessment with respect to non-registered dealers depends, on the issue of a notice such as is prescribed by s. 10 and rule 22 and that as no such notice had been issued in the case of the appellant, the assessment proceedings must be held to be incompetent, if the registration certificate is invalid.

arguments.court_reasoning: Jurisdiction derives from s.3 and s.11 not s.10 which is procedural; voluntary returns submitted; mere irregularity not nullity; collateral attack not allowed

arguments.claim: Taxing authorities derive jurisdiction to make assessments under s.3 and s.11, not under s.10 which is purely procedural

anchor.surface_text: We see no force in this contention. The taxing authorities derive their jurisdiction to make assessments under s. 3 and 11 of the Act, and not under s. 10, which is purely procedural.

arguments.claim: Appellant submitted returns voluntarily under s.10(1) so cannot contend proceedings without jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had itself, acting under s. 10 (1) been submitting voluntarily returns on which the assessments had been made and it is not idle for it to contend that the proceedings taken on its own returns are without jurisdiction.

arguments.claim: Fundamental distinction between want of jurisdiction (nullity, open to collateral attack) and irregular assumption of jurisdiction (not nullity, only direct challenge)

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it should be remembered that there is a fundamental distinction between want of jurisdiction and irregular assumption of jurisdiction, and that whereas an order passed by an authority with respect to a matter over which it has no jurisdiction is a nullity and is open to collateral attack, an order passed by an authority which has jurisdiction over the matter, but has assumed it otherwise than in the mode prescribed by law, is not a nullity.

arguments.claim: Even if proceedings against non-registered dealer without notice under s.10(1), it is mere irregularity in assumption of jurisdiction; assessment not without jurisdiction; no suit lies to impeach on that ground; a fortiori when dealer submitted returns
Even if registration under s.8 bad, no effect on validity of assessment proceedings under the Act
s.21 bars jurisdiction of civil courts to entertain suits questioning orders under the Act; unnecessary to decide if present suit maintainable

holdings.text: The appellant was liable to pay the tax under the Act irrespective of whether the registration under s. 8 was valid or not. That liability arose under s. 4 which is the charging section.

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment the High Court is clearly correct in its view that the appellant was liable to pay the tax under the Act irrespective of whether the registration under s. 8 was valid or not. That liability arose under s. 4 which is the charging ,section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Liability imposed by charging s.4 independent of procedural registration under s.8; s.8(1) prohibits unregistered business but does not negate tax obligation.

holdings.text: This liability is not conditional on the registration of the dealer under s. 8.

anchor.surface_text: This liability is not conditional on the registration of the dealer under s. 8. Section 8 (1) enacts that no dealer shall, while being liable to pay tax under this Act carry on business as a dealer unless he has been registered as such and possesses a registration certificate .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.4(1)(a) imposes tax on qualifying dealers without reference to registration; s.8 is regulatory.

holdings.text: A dealer who fails to get himself registered would be hit by s. 8(1) and may lose the benefit conferred by s. 11(1) but the Act does not put him in a better position than a dealer who has got himself registered under s. 8(1) and absolve him from his liability to pay tax under s. 4.

anchor.surface_text: Section 11 (1) provides that If the Commissioner is satisfied that the returns furnished by a registered dealer in respect of any period are correct and complete, he shall assess the dealer on them. These provisions do not, to any extent effect the substantive liability to be assessed to tax which is imposed by s. 4.A dealer who fails to get himself registered would be hit by s. 8 (1) and may loss the benefit conferred by s. 11 (1) but the Act does not put him in a better position than a dealer who has got himself registered under s. 8 (1) and absolve him from his liability to pay tax under s. 4.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction: s.11 provides procedural benefit for registered dealers but s.4 substantive liability unaffected; invalid registration equivalent to none.

holdings.text: The taxing authorities derive their jurisdiction to make assessments under s. 3 and 11 of the Act, and not under s. 10, which is purely procedural.

anchor.surface_text: We see no force in this contention. The taxing authorities derive their jurisdiction to make assessments under s. 3 and 11 of the Act, and not under s. 10, which is purely procedural.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction stems from appointment under s.3 and assessment power s.11; s.10 and rule 22 merely regulate procedure for returns.

holdings.text: The appellant had itself, acting under s. 10(1) been submitting voluntarily returns on which the assessments had been made and it is not idle for it to contend that the proceedings taken on its own returns are without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant had itself, acting under s. 10 (1) been submitting voluntarily returns on which the assessments had been made and it is not idle for it to contend that the proceedings taken on its own returns are without jurisdiction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Voluntary submission under s.10(1) invokes jurisdiction; estoppel-like bar to deny.

holdings.text: There is a fundamental distinction between want of jurisdiction and irregular assumption of jurisdiction, and that whereas an order passed by an authority with respect to a matter over which it has no jurisdiction is a nullity and is open to collateral attack, an order passed by an authority which has jurisdiction over the matter, but has assumed it otherwise than in the mode prescribed by law, is not a nullity.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it should be remembered that there is a fundamental distinction between want of jurisdiction and irregular assumption of jurisdiction, and that whereas an order passed by an authority with respect to a matter over which it has no jurisdiction is a nullity and is open to collateral attack, an order passed by an authority which has jurisdiction over the matter, but has assumed it otherwise than in the mode prescribed by law, is not a nullity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Established doctrine distinguishes total lack (void ab initio, collateral challenge) from procedural irregularity (valid unless directly challenged).

holdings.text: Even if the proceedings for assessment were taken against a non-registered dealer without the issue of a notice under s. 10(1) that would be a mere irregularity in the assumption of jurisdiction and the order of assessment passed in those proceedings cannot be held to be without jurisdiction and no suit will lie for impeaching them on the ground that s. 10(1) had not been followed. This must a fortiori be so when the appellant has itself submitted to jurisdiction and made a return.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying jurisdiction distinction to facts: missing notice is irregularity; voluntary returns strengthen validity; bars collateral suit attack.

holdings.text: Even if the registration of the appellant as a dealer under s. 8 is bad that has no effect on the validity of the proceedings taken against it under the Act and the assessment of tax made thereunder.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: independent liability, procedural nature of registration, jurisdiction intact, irregularity not fatal.

holdings.text: s. 21 of the Act bars the jurisdiction of Civil Courts to entertain suits calling in question any orders passed by the authorities under the Act, and in the view which we have taken it is unnecessary to go into the question whether in view of this section the present suit is maintainable.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Observation on bar to suits; not decided as unnecessary.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly agree with the learned Judges that even if the registration of the appellant as a dealer under s. 8 is bad that has no effect on the validity of the proceedings taken against it under the Act and the assessment of tax made thereunder.

outcome.relief_summary: Validity of registration under s.8 does not affect tax liability under s.4 or validity of assessment proceedings; suit for refund denied

anchor.surface_text: This liability is not conditional on the registration of the dealer under s. 8. Section 8 (1) enacts that no dealer shall, while being liable to pay tax under this Act carry on business as a dealer unless he has been registered as such and possesses a registration certificate .

We accordingly agree with the learned Judges that even if the registration of the appellant as a dealer under s. 8 is bad that has no effect on the validity of the proceedings taken against it under the Act and the assessment of tax made thereunder.

Section 11 (1) provides that If the Commissioner is satisfied that the returns furnished by a registered dealer in respect of any period are correct and complete, he shall assess the dealer on them. These provisions do not, to any extent effect the substantive liability to be assessed to tax which is imposed by s. 4.A dealer who fails to get himself registered would be hit by s. 8 (1) and may loss the benefit conferred by s. 11 (1) but the Act does not put him in a better position than a dealer who has got himself registered under s. 8 (1) and absolve him from his liability to pay tax under s. 4.

We accordingly agree with the learned Judges that even if the registration of the appellant as a dealer under s. 8 is bad that has no effect on the validity of the proceedings taken against it under the Act and the assessment of tax made thereunder.

We accordingly agree with the learned Judges that even if the registration of the appellant as a dealer under s. 8 is bad that has no effect on the validity of the proceedings taken against it under the Act and the assessment of tax made thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: In this connection it should be remembered that there is a fundamental distinction between want of jurisdiction and irregular assumption of jurisdiction, and that whereas an order passed by an authority with respect to a matter over which it has no jurisdiction is a nullity and is open to collateral attack, an order passed by an authority which has jurisdiction over the matter, but has assumed it otherwise than in the mode prescribed by law, is not a nullity.

We accordingly agree with the learned Judges that even if the registration of the appellant as a dealer under s. 8 is bad that has no effect on the validity of the proceedings taken against it under the Act and the assessment of tax made thereunder.

edges.explanation: Holding h7 treats absence of s.10(1) notice as mere irregularity, undercutting strict enforcement of concept c13's notice requirement.
